hopobject.body:
For example, instead of looking up the BeagleBone System Reference Manual and determine that pin 3 on connector P8 corresponds to GPIO1[6], and that, in turn, corresponds to /sys/class/gpio/gpio38, then maxing sure the pin muxing is set to mode 7 + input + pull-down (via /sys/kernel/debug/omap_mux/gpmac_ad), that the GPIO is set to input (via /sys/class/gpio/gpio38/direction -- still with me?), Bonelib makes it as simple as: 

BeagleBone::gpio* inp = BeagleBone::gpio::P8(3);
inp.configure(BeagleBone::pin::IN, BeagleBone::pin::PD);

bool = inp.get();

voila!

Find the full user documentation at http://sourceforge.net/p/bonelib/wiki/Home/
hopobject.shortdesc: Library of C++/PERL objects providing a high-level abstraction of the BeagleBone peripherals
